item.title: Assorted Things

  2. Think more about what to focus on - by Henrik Karlsson

    “Ironically, the left, now alarmed by the federal governmentâ€™s intrusive reach, bears direct responsibility for crafting the very legal weapons wielded against the universities it dominates.”
  4. Vibe Coding, Vibe Checking, and Vibe Blogging
    Using Generative AI for Personal-Scale Projects
  5. The Third Humbling of Humanity
    What will be left of our self-conception once artificial intelligence becomes better than us at writing poems or making movies?
  6. On Jagged AGI: o3, Gemini 2.5, and everything after
    I myself have noted the big difference in 2.5 pro and what came before.

item.title: Weekly Assorted Things
item.description:
1. Intelligence and individual differences in astrological belief.
    â€œOf our psychological measures we find intelligence, as measured with Wordsum, to have the largest effect size, negatively predicting belief in astrology. Education also predicts disbelief, supporting the â€œsuperficial knowledgeâ€ hypothesis. Measures of religiosity and spirituality had null effects, in contradiction of the â€œmetaphysical uncertaintyâ€ hypothesis that a need for metaphysical beliefs causes one to believe in astrology. We find that right-wing individuals are less likely to believe in astrology, in contradiction to Theodore W. Adornoâ€™s â€œauthoritarianâ€ of astrology. We also find no effect scientific trust on astrological belief. â€œ Oof. Via Tyler Cowen.
  2. My LLM codegen workflow atm | Harper Reed’s Blog
    Really great overview. Golden age for indie devs?
  3. New York Times goes all-in on internal AI tools | Semafor
    From actively suing to actively using. Interesting pivot. As an NYT subscriber, I look forward to seeing how it pans out.
  4. AI Essentials for Tech Executives
    Lots of useful stuff here, particularly around testing.
  5. Run LLMs on macOS using llm-mlx and Appleâ€™s MLX framework
    Leveraging Apple silicon. I will certainly hone this a spin on my machine.
  6. The Death of Government Expertise (The Atlantic)
    â€œPopulists are generally wary of experts, especially those who work for the government, but Musk is no man of the people: He is the richest human being in the world, and he runs major companies that rely both on government-provided expertise and significant government subsidies. As my colleague Anne Applebaum wrote, â€œMusk has made no attempt to professionally audit or even understand many of the programs being cutâ€â€”a willful indifference that gives away the game.â€
